messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Reinforcement learning for automatic quadrilateral mesh generation: a soft actor-critic approach

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper proposes, implements, and evaluates a reinforcement learning (RL)-based computational framework for automatic mesh generation. Mesh generation plays a fundamental role in numerical simulations in the area of computer aided design and engineering (CAD/E). It is identified as one of the critical issues in the NASA CFD Vision 2030 Study. Existing mesh generation methods suffer from high computational complexity, low mesh quality in complex geometries, and speed limitations. These methods and tools, including commercial software packages, are typically semiautomatic and they need inputs or help from human experts. By formulating the mesh generation as a Markov decision process (MDP) problem, we are able to use a state-of-the-art reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm called ‚Äúsoft actor-critic‚Äù to automatically learn from trials the policy of actions for mesh generation. The implementation of this RL algorithm for mesh generation allows us to build a fully automatic mesh generation system without human intervention and any extra clean-up operations, which fills the gap in the existing mesh generation tools. In the experiments to compare with two representative commercial software packages, our system demonstrates promising performance with respect to scalability, generalizability, and effectiveness.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "CUBIT geometry and mesh generation toolkit 15.2 user documentation",
        "Paving: a new approach to automated quadrilateral mesh generation",
        "The influence of pattern similarity and transfer learning upon training of a base perceptron b2",
        "Neural ordinary differential equations",
        "Constrained delaunay triangulations",
        "Convolutional neural networks on graphs with fast localized spectral filtering",
        "Towards fully regular quad mesh generation",
        "Addressing function approximation error in actor-critic methods",
        "Gmsh: a 3-D finite element mesh generator with built-in pre-and post-processing facilities",
        "Construction of curvilinear co-ordinate systems and applications to mesh generation",
        "Guidelines for reinforcement learning in healthcare",
        "Neural mesh flow: 3D manifold mesh generation via diffeomorphic flows",
        "Soft actor-critic: off-policy maximum entropy deep reinforcement learning with a stochastic actor",
        "Soft actor-critic algorithms and applications",
        "Digital engineering transformation with trustworthy AI for industry 4.0",
        "Trustworthy AI for digital engineering transformation",
        "Achieving finite element mesh quality via optimization of the jacobian matrix norm and associated quantities. Part II‚Äîa framework for volume mesh optimization and the condition number of the jacobian matrix",
        "The verdict geometric quality library",
        "Continuous control with deep reinforcement learning",
        "Distributed poly-square mapping for large-scale semi-structured quad mesh generation",
        "Reinforcement learning for combinatorial optimization: a survey",
        "Asynchronous methods for deep reinforcement learning",
        "Composite algorithm for adaptive mesh construction based on self-organizing maps",
        "A self-learning finite element extraction system based on reinforcement learning",
        "How to teach neural networks to mesh: application on 2-D simplicial contours",
        "Stable-baselines3: reliable reinforcement learning implementations",
        "A frontal delaunay quad mesh generator using the l‚àû norm",
        "Blossom-quad: a non-uniform quadrilateral mesh generator using a minimum-cost perfect-matching algorithm",
        "Proximal policy optimization algorithms",
        "Unstructured mesh generation",
        "Mastering the game of go with deep neural networks and tree search",
        "CFD vision 2030 study: a path to revolutionary computational aerosciences",
        "Reinforcement learning: an introduction",
        "Reinforcement learning: an introduction, second edition",
        "A robust combinatorial approach to reduce singularities in quadrilateral meshes",
        "Œ±ùõºmst: a robust unified algorithm for quadrilateral mesh adaptation in 2D and 3D",
        "Pointer networks",
        "Pixel2mesh: generating 3D mesh models from single rgb images",
        "Deep reinforcement learning for nlp",
        "Redesign of the paving algorithm: robustness enhancements through element by element meshing",
        "Reinforcement learning for adaptive mesh refinement",
        "An angular method with position control for block mesh squareness improvement",
        "An ann-based element extraction method for automatic mesh generation",
        "Knowledge-based free mesh generation of quadrilateral elements in two-dimensional domains",
        "Understanding design activities through computer simulation",
        "Meshingnet: a new mesh generation method based on deep learning",
        "A comprehensive survey on transfer learning",
        "Modeling purposeful adaptive behavior with the principle of maximum causal entropy"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Reinforcement learning for automatic quadrilateral mesh generation: a soft actor-critic approach, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
